{|{{Infobox ship begin}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image=[[Image:USS PGM-2.jpg|300px]] |Ship caption=''PGM-2'' after her conversion }} {{Infobox ship class overview |Builders= |Operators= |Class before= |Class after=''PGM-9'' class motor gunboat |Subclasses= |Built range=1942-1943 |In commission range= |Total ships building= |Total ships planned=8 |Total ships completed=8 |Total ships cancelled= |Total ships active= |Total ships laid up= |Total ships lost=1 |Total ships retired= |Total ships preserved= }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship type=Patrol gunboat, motor (PGM) |Ship displacement=95 tons |Ship length=110 feet 10 inches |Ship beam=23 feet |Ship draft=10 feet 10 inches |Ship propulsion=*2 × 1,540bhp Electro-Motive Corp. 16-184A diesel engines *2 × shafts |Ship speed=21 knots |Ship range= |Ship complement= |Ship sensors= |Ship EW= |Ship armament=Varies |Ship armor= |Ship aircraft= |Ship aircraft facilities= |Ship notes= }} |}
The '''''PGM-1'' class motor gunboats''' were a class of eight gunboats converted for the [[United States Navy]] from 1943-1944 and were succeeded by the ''PGM-9'' class motor gunboat. All eight ''PGM-1''s were converted from [[SC-497 class submarine chaser]]s. The ''PGM-1''s were created to support [[PT boats]] in the Pacific, but were too slow to keep up. The ''PGM-1'' was discontinued and the ''PGM-9'', also too slow, was shifted to support [[minesweeping ships]] instead.
''PGM-7'' was the only ''PGM-1'' lost in World War II. The others were sent to the Foreign Liquidation Commission in 1947. Their exact fate is unknown.
==Sources== *[http://www.ww2pcsa.org/subchaser.html INFORMATION ON WWII SCs]
